mainmatter.p: The element of \mathbb {R}R\mathbb {R}R is a Dedekind Cut in \mathbb {Q}Q\mathbb {Q}Q. \mathbb {R} := \{ L | (L,R) \text { is a Dedekind Cut} \} R:={L∣(L,R) is a Dedekind Cut} \mathbb {R} := \{ L | (L,R) \text { is a Dedekind Cut} \} R:={L∣(L,R) is a Dedekind Cut}

frontmatter.title: The Construction of \mathbb {R}R\mathbb {R}R

mainmatter.p: We start constructing \mathbb {R}R\mathbb {R}R from \mathbb {Q}Q\mathbb {Q}Q by a way that it satisfies the existence theorem, the core of construction.
There exists an ordered field \mathbb {R}R\mathbb {R}R that satisfies the least upper bound property. Moreover \mathbb {R}R\mathbb {R}R contains \mathbb {Q}Q\mathbb {Q}Q as a subfield.
The least-upper-bound property mentioned above is defined:
A set SSSS has the least upper bound property if every non-empty subset TTTT of SSSS that is bounded above has a least upper bound \sup Tsup⁡T\sup TsupT.

Why do we need the least-upper-bound property? Consider the set S = \{ x \in \mathbb {Q} | x^2 < 2 \}S={x∈Q∣x2<2}S = \{ x \in \mathbb {Q} | x^2 < 2 \}S={x∈Q∣x2<2}. SSSS is bounded above by 2222, but it does not have a least upper bound in \mathbb {Q}Q\mathbb {Q}Q. Therefore we can't express \sqrt {2}2\sqrt {2}2​ in field \mathbb {Q}Q\mathbb {Q}Q since some "gaps" exist. This fact motivates us to construct a more complete field \mathbb {R}R\mathbb {R}R. We have constructed \mathbb {Q}Q\mathbb {Q}Q from \mathbb {Z}Z\mathbb {Z}Z, and now we construct \mathbb {R}R\mathbb {R}R from \mathbb {Q}Q\mathbb {Q}Q.

Then we should find a way to express "\sqrt {2}2\sqrt {2}2​" using \mathbb {Q}Q\mathbb {Q}Q. A crucial idea is approximating \sqrt {2}2\sqrt {2}2​ by a sequence of rational numbers. \sqrt {2} := \{ p^2<2 \lor p<0, p \in \mathbb {Q} \} 2:={p2<2∨p<0,p∈Q} \sqrt {2} := \{ p^2<2 \lor p<0, p \in \mathbb {Q} \} 2​:={p2<2∨p<0,p∈Q} We can cut the number axis into two pieces by \sqrt {2}2\sqrt {2}2​, such cut is called a Dedekind cut. A cut should be well-defined rather than just an intuitive concept.

As we use set theory to construct \mathbb {R}R\mathbb {R}R, it motivates us to define Dedekind cut as a set. It should satisfies some properties: Can't be empty or the whole \mathbb {Q}Q\mathbb {Q}Q Closed downward Contains not the largest number A formal definition is given below:

A Dedekind cut is a partition of the rationals \mathbb {Q}Q\mathbb {Q}Q into two non-empty sets LLLL and RRRR such that: L \neq \emptysetL≠∅L \neq \emptysetL=∅ R \neq \emptysetR≠∅R \neq \emptysetR=∅ if x,y \in \mathbb {Q}, xx,y∈Q,x<yx,y \in \mathbb {Q}, x<yx,y∈Q,x<y and y \in Ly∈Ly \in Ly∈L then x \in Lx∈Lx \in Lx∈L if p \in Lp∈Lp \in Lp∈L then exists q \in Lq∈Lq \in Lq∈L such that pp<qp<qp<q
Now we can defined the real number as a set of Dedekind cuts.

The element of \mathbb {R}R\mathbb {R}R is a Dedekind Cut in \mathbb {Q}Q\mathbb {Q}Q. \mathbb {R} := \{ L | (L,R) \text { is a Dedekind Cut} \} R:={L∣(L,R) is a Dedekind Cut} \mathbb {R} := \{ L | (L,R) \text { is a Dedekind Cut} \} R:={L∣(L,R) is a Dedekind Cut}

Now define the order relation on \mathbb {R}R\mathbb {R}R. We have defined \mathbb {R}R\mathbb {R}R as the set of Dedekind cuts, so we can define the strict partial order relation <<<< on \mathbb {R}R\mathbb {R}R by the set operation \subset⊂\subset⊂. The irreflexive, asymmetric and transitive properties are trivial.

A Dedekind cut is a partition of the rationals \mathbb {Q}Q\mathbb {Q}Q into two non-empty sets LLLL and RRRR such that: L \neq \emptysetL≠∅L \neq \emptysetL=∅ R \neq \emptysetR≠∅R \neq \emptysetR=∅ if x,y \in \mathbb {Q}, xx,y∈Q,x<yx,y \in \mathbb {Q}, x<yx,y∈Q,x<y and y \in Ly∈Ly \in Ly∈L then x \in Lx∈Lx \in Lx∈L if p \in Lp∈Lp \in Lp∈L then exists q \in Lq∈Lq \in Lq∈L such that pp<qp<qp<q
